review.title: Predictive Clinical Decision Support System with RNN Encoding and Tensor Decoding
review.abstract: With the introduction of the Electric Health Records, large amounts of digital data become available for analysis and decision support. When physicians are prescribing treatments to a patient, they need to consider a large range of data variety and volume, making decisions increasingly complex. Machine learning based Clinical Decision Support systems can be a solution to the data challenges. In this work we focus on a class of decision support in which the physicians' decision is directly predicted. Concretely, the model would assign higher probabilities to decisions that it presumes the physician are more likely to make. Thus the CDS system can provide physicians with rational recommendations. We also address the problem of correlation in target features: Often a physician is required to make multiple (sub-)decisions in a block, and that these decisions are mutually dependent. We propose a solution to the target correlation problem using a tensor factorization model. In order to handle the patients' historical information as sequential data, we apply the so-called Encoder-Decoder-Framework which is based on Recurrent Neural Networks (RNN) as encoders and a tensor factorization model as a decoder, a combination which is novel in machine learning. With experiments with real-world datasets we show that the proposed model does achieve better prediction performances.

metadata.title: Predictive Clinical Decision Support System with RNN Encoding and Tensor Decoding

sections.heading: Sara Y. Brucker
sections.text: Department of Gynaecology and Obstetrics, University Hospital Tübingen, GermanySara.Brucker @ med.uni-tuebingen.deVolker Tresp Ludwig-Maximilians-University Munich, Munich, Siemens AG, Corporate Technology, Munichvolker.tresp @ siemens.com

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: With the introduction of electromobility (EHR), large amounts of digital data will be made available for analysis and decision-making, which, once thoroughly cleaned and processed, could allow for a wide variety of analysis and modeling tasks.

sections.heading: 2 Decision Support for Breast Cancer Therapies
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 2.1 Data Description
sections.text: The data provided by the PRAEGNANT Study Network [6] was collected from patients suffering from metastatic breast cancer. After pre-treatment, we were able to extract information on 1245 patients: the 1) basic information, 2) primary tumor and 3) history of metastatic disease prior to entry into the study. These data are considered static and consist of a total of 26 characteristics of binary, categorical or real types. We perform performeddummy coding in the previous two cases and were able to extract for each patient i a static trait vector associated with mi-R114The sequential information consists of two categories. Firstly, 4) local recurrence, 5) metastatic and 6) visits include information on clinical events, such as progression and live status, which we refer to as events. Secondly, there are three types of therapy information: 7) radiotherapy categories, 8) systemic therapies, and 9) each of which are categorical therapies.

sections.heading: 2.2 Modeling Solution
sections.text: First, we associate the sequential and static data on a patient i up to a time step > > by constructing a latent representation vector: a < i, t > = (g ({x [t ′] i) t ′ = 1) | σ (H Tmi)), (1) where g refers to an RNN encoder that outputs only the last hidden state in the input sequence {x [t ′] i) tt ′ = 1. This approach was first proposed by [9], where it has been proven that such an RNN encoder is capable of encoding all information in a sequence of variable length into a single real vector. We use this aspect of such RNN encoders and apply this vector to represent the patient-specific temporal information encoded by < i, t > index. We augment this information by linking it to the static patient information encoded by a matrix-linear.

sections.heading: 3 Experiments
sections.text: We point 80% of all 1245 patients to the training plan and 20% to the test set. Then we ask all the static and sequential information as well as the goals underlying the training patients and test patients. Since the RNN model implements the LSTM with the hidden state of size 25 and the mapping of the static information into a latent size 15 space using a simple log linear mapping of matrix H as Figure 2, we implement a rank 5 Tucker-3 model. We apply 0.1 dropout regulation to the RNN part and 0.1 comb regulation to the rest of the parameters in the model.

sections.heading: 4 Discussions
sections.text: The main contribution of our work is to propose a new model architecture by combining an RNN encoder with a tensor factorization model, both of which share a common latent representation. Thetensor factorization component models the common likelihood of target characteristics rather than thresholds. We therefore suspect that our model is capable of detecting correlations between target characteristics, which are often relevant for the modelling of clinical decisions. We show that the proposed model achieves better predictive results in experiments with real data sets. In this paper, we only perform predictions of radiotherapy. We will extend our work to the other two therapies in our dataset: systemic therapy and operations. Specifically, the first model has three objectives and would require a 4-D tensor.

metadata.abstractText: With the introduction of the Electric Health Records (EHR), large amounts of digital data become available for analysis and decision support [1]. These data, as soon as carefully cleaned and well preprocessed, could enable a large variety of analysis and modeling tasks that can improve healthcare services and patients experience [2]. When physicians are prescribing treatments to a patient, they need to consider a large range of data variety and volume. These data might include patients’ genetic profiles and their entire historical clinical protocols. With the growing amounts of data decision making becomes increasingly complex. Machine learning based Clinical Decision Support (CDS) systems can be a solution to the data challenges [3] [4] [5]. Machine learning models and decision support systems have been proven to be capable of handling —and actually even profiting from— large amount of data in high dimensional space and with complex dependency characteristics. Some powerful machine learning models generate abstract and yet informative features from a usually sparse feature space.
